description.narrative: Improve macroeconomic and financial governance in MEFMI member countries

Stöd till "the Macroeconomic and Financial Management Institute of Eastern and Southern Africa" (MEFMI). MEFMI är ett regionalt institut som syftar till att skapa förhållanden för ekonomisk tillväxt genom att stärka den makroekonomiska och finansiella ledningen via institutionell och mänsklig kapacitetsbyggnad i regionen.

Support to the Macroeconomic and Financial Management Institute of Eastern and Southern Africa (MEFMI). MEFMI is a regionally owned institute aiming at creating conditions for economic growth by strengthening macroeconomic and financial management through institutional and human capacity building in the region.

description.narrative: The MEFMI Phase IV has been considered an important capacity building investment with the overall objective to improve macroeconomic and financial management and performance that supports economic growth and poverty reduction in member countries in the Eastern and Southern Africa region. Examples of achieved results include capacity building provided to national officials in the target countries, which has resulted in member countries adopting modern legislation and good practices in macroeconomic and financial sector management. According to a recent IMF report, Sub-Saharan African nations are at growing risk of debt distress because of heavy borrowing and gaping deficits, despite an overall uptick in economic growth. The assessment comes as African countries continue to tap international debt markets and issue record levels of debt in foreign currencies, spurred on by insatiable investor demand for yields. MEFMI has included capacity building to member states related to dept management. Some of the specific achievements in this regard are (i) updated legal frameworks and improved coordination of debt management responsibilities and (ii) improvements in the formulation and implementation of sound and adequate legal and policy frameworks for domestic financial markets development in its member countries. Compilation and reporting of Public Debt Statistics in the region met internationally accepted standards as at the end of 2016. All member countries subscribed to regular reporting of statistics to World Bank and IMF, while nine or 69% of the countries were publishing annual public debt statistical bulletins or their equivalent, compared to 30% countries in 2011. The stability of the financial sector is also depending on the regulation of the Non-Bank Financial Institutions (NBFIs). Support to MEFMI has contributed to the develpment of a framework which is a rating mechanism to be applied when supervising microfinance institutions. Sweden has put specific emphasis on gender analysis and the need to mainstream gender into specific interventions/programmes. An output achievement is that female participation has increased from 36% in the previous phase to 43% in the present phase. This was due to continous follow-up with member countries to nominate females to participate in all MEFMI activities. Most of the member countries also had similar focus on the need for increased female participation. Find more examples in the Conclusion on Performance dated 2018-02-27.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
